History of Present Illness:
Admit to surgery ___
===========================
History obtained primarily from chart and ___ 
is a ___ w/ hx of dementia, BPH w/ chronic foley, recurrent 
UTIs, pacemaker, on eliquis, who is presenting to the ___ as 
txf'r for ___ after a fall from his bed. He was being 
treated for UTI in the setting of having an obstructed foley. A 
CT head was obtained showing an IPH and he was subsequently 
___ here to the ___. Neurosurgery was consulted, and a repeat 
CT head showed no interval change in size of IPH. A CT A/P was 
also obtained showing a R rib 9 fx. Per report, a CT C-spine was 
also obtained at ___ that showed no acute fx.

Transfer to Medicine ___
===============================
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with hypertension, BPH with 
chronic urinary retention w/ h/o UTIs (chronic foley at nursing 
home), pacemaker for SSS, on eliquis for afib and PE ___ year 
prior, who presented as OSH transfer from ___ after he 
presented there after a fall from his bed. He subsequently c/o
right hip pain and was brought to the ___ where a CT 
head showed small left temporal-parietal hemorrhage thought to 
be traumatic in nature. A CT A/P showed a R rib 9 fx. CT C-spine 
showed no acute fx per report. 

Patient was then transferred to ___ for neurosurgical 
evaluation. A repeat CT was stable. There was no indication for 
acute surgical intervention. The patient reportedly remained at 
his neurological baseline throughout. On the morning of ___, 
the patient acutely decompensated in mental status, reportedly 
more
somnolent.  Stat head CT demonstrated no significant interval 
change in IPH. Neurology consulted for AMS. 

At the time of transfer the patient reports he is doing Ok and 
denies any pain. He was somnolent and unable to open his eyes. 
Per records in the chart the patient was treated with ampicillin 
at the nursing home from ___ for UTI.

IMAGING
=======
CXR ___
No acute cardiopulmonary findings such as pneumothorax. No 
grossly displaced rib fractures were identified on this limited 
frontal radiograph.

Pelvic XR ___ Bilateral total hip arthroplasty, without 
evidence of perihardware complications such as loosening or 
fracture. Paget's disease of the pelvis again noted.

CT head ___
Small focus of intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the left temporal 
lobe cortex unchanged since prior study.  No new hemorrhage.

CT A/P ___
1. Acute right ninth rib fracture.
2. Unchanged minimally complex small left pleural effusion.
3. No evidence of solid organ injury.  No pneumoperitoneum or 
definite free fluid within the abdomen.
4. Bilateral perinephric stranding and second bladder wall 
likely related to history of chronic outlet obstruction.

CT head ___
1. Stable left temporal lobe hyperdensity, similar to prior exam 
without evidence of surrounding edema or significant mass 
effect.  There is no evidence of new large vascular territory 
infarction, or new areas of hemorrhage.

EEG ___
IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal continuous ICU EEG monitoring 
study because
of mild generalized background slowing, with activity 
predominantly in the
theta range reaching a maximum of 6 hz. This indicates a mild 
encephalopathy, which is nonspecific in etiology. There are no 
epileptiform discharges or electrographic seizures seen. 
Compared to the day prior study, there are no significant 
changes.

Shoulder Xray ___
No acute osseous abnormality identified.  Small mineralized 
density projects adjacent to the left humeral head, likely 
reflective of calcific tendinopathy.

Head CT ___
1. Stable small hyperdensity in the left posterior temporal lobe 
without
significant edema.
2. No evidence for new intracranial abnormalities.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE
=====================
___ with h/o dementia, HTN, BPH with chronic Foley, SSS s/p 
pacemaker, A-fib on Eliquis who presented s/p fall, found to 
have new small and stable IPH with no surgical intervention 
indicated and repeat CT Head was stable. Hospital course 
complicated by UTI and altered mental status, s/p 10 day course 
of CTX, cefpodoxime. Mental status improved to baseline A&O ___ 
secondary to underlying dementia. During hospitalization, he 
also has had several periods of unresponsiveness lasting up to 
several hours, where he would only withdraw to painful stimuli. 
His neice/HCP reported that he has had these for many years with 
extensive work-up unrevealing. He had a CT Head which showed no 
progression of the ICH. Neuro was consulted and EEG was done 
with no signs of seizure activity. These periods were felt to be 
psychiatric in nature. 

=======================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
=======================

MEDICATIONS:
- New Meds: Labetalol 100 BID, Ramelteon 8 mg PO QHS 
- Stopped Meds: Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg PO DAILY  
- Changed Meds: None

FOLLOW-UP 
- Follow up: PCP, ___
- ___ required after discharge: None
- Incidental findings: None

OTHER ISSUES:
***Patient has episodes of unresponsiveness (only withdraws to 
pain). He usually comes back to being responsive in a couple of 
hours with no specific intervention. He needs to be reorientated 
and placed on delirium precautions, which help his mental status 
greatly.***
- Avoid using antipsychotics in this patient if he become 
agitated since his BP will drop. He does well with redirection
- HTN: If BPs continues to be high, consider titrating 
labetalol. He was discharged on 100 BID; Goal SBP 120-150
- Patient has acute right ninth rib fracture 
- Chronic foley in place, continue management per protocol

# CONTACT: ___ ___
# CODE: DNR/DNI (confirmed with HCP)

=====================================

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:

# Delirium - Etiology of delirium most likely due to UTI in this 
patient who has poor baseline cognitive reserve. EEG was done 
for concern for seizure but did not show any epileptiform 
discharges or seizures. He also has increased somnolence during 
his first few days of this hospotalization that may be due to 
repeated administrations of IV antipsychotic medication. TSH, 
B12 WNL. No signs of cirrhosis. Triggered on ___ for AMS. Mental 
status improved in a couple of hours with no specific 
intervention. Per HCP he had similar events of unresponsiveness 
in the past which self resolved in a few hours usually, and he 
also had extensive workup for seizures. Workup for AMS on ___ 
included head CT which was negative showing stable IPH, EKG - 
normal, UCx and BCx were resent. UCx showed mixed flora iso of 
no fever/leukocytosis. BCx were negative. Patient was continued 
on ___ mg PO DAILY during this admission.

# Intraparenchymal hemorrhage - Etiology initially thought to be 
due to trauma but it's unclear if this is feasible given that 
the IPH is deep and there is no obvious trauma seen on the 
patient's head. The thought is that the IPH occurred and 
subsequently had a fall because of it. Due to the location and 
small size of the hemorrhage it is possible it is a bleed in a 
vessel with cerebral amyloid angiopathy. No neurosurgical 
intervention was recommended. Anticoagulation was initially held 
iso of bleeding, but after a repeat head CT scan which showed no 
change in IPH size apixaban was restarted, as well as Aspirin.

# Urinary tract infection: although patient has a urine culture 
that shows fecal contamination, given his altered mental status 
and white count that is improving with antibiotics, he was 
empirically treated for UTI with a 10 day course of cefpodozime 
100 Q12. Repeat urine culture on ___ showed again mixed flora, 
however patient was asymptomatic with no white count, fever or 
urinary symptoms. 
 
# Atrial fibrillation  - On Eliquis and Aspirin at home which 
was held temporarily due to intraparenchymal hemorrhage. Both 
were restarted by the time of discharge.

# Hypertension - Initially patient was receiving metoprolol, 
however BPs were running high so metoprolol was switched to 
labetalol 100 BID and BPs lowered around 120-130s systolic. If 
pressure continue to be high, labetalol can be uptitrated.  

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS:

# BPH with chronic urinary retention - patient with chronic 
foley 

# Sick sinus syndrome - patient with pacemaker 
 
# Depression - Patient continued on Sertraline 50 mg PO DAILY  

>30 minutes was spent on discharge planning and coordination

Primary Diagnosis
=================
Intraparenchimal hemorrhage

Secondary Diagnosis
===================
Urinary tract infection
Atrial Fibrillation
Hypertension
Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia
Sick sinus syndrome

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Lethargic but arousable.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr ___,

You came to ___ as a transfer from ___ after a fall 
from your bed. You were found to have a bleed inside your brain. 
Please see more details listed below about what happened while 
you were in the hospital and your instructions for what to do 
after leaving the hospital.

It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the 
best! 

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL:
- We did a scan of your head which showed a bleed which remained 
stable in size at repeat scan
- Neurosurgery was consulted and did not think that you needed 
to have surgery
- A CT of your chest showed a fracture in one of your ribs which 
probably happened when you fell from the bed
- We did an analysis of your urine which showed you have a 
urinary tract infection, so we treated you for that infection 
with antibiotics. You completed the course of antibiotics in the 
hospital
- We initially held your anticoagulation since you had a brain 
bleed, but we restarted both Aspirin and Apixaban by the time of 
your discharge
- We monitored your blood pressure carefully and we made a 
change in your heart medication
- You had an EEG (a tests that monitors the electrical activity 
of your brain) which showed no evidence of seizure activity

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL:
- Please follow up with your health care providers at the 
nursing facility as well as with your other providers (see 
below)
- Please take all of your medications as prescribed (see below).
- Seek medical attention if you have Dizziness or 
lightheadedness, Numbness or tingling, Change in vision, 
Confusion, Headache, Weakness in arm, leg, or face
Difficulty walking, Difficulty talking, Loss of balance, 
Incontinence of urine or stool, Difficulty urinating, Blood in 
urine, Foul smelling urine, Leg pain, Leg swelling, Leg redness, 
Shortness of breath, Chest pain or other symptoms of concern. 

 
Followup Instructions:

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
